Each non-chosen creature must make a Constitution saving throw when it enters the spell's area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there. On a failed save, a target takes {@damage 1d8} bludgeoning damage and becomes {@condition blinded} for one minute. On a successful save, a target takes half as much damage, but suffers no other effect.
At the end of each of its turns, a target can make a Constitution saving throw. On a success, the condition ends.
Dust Trap

Trap. When Dust Trap is triggered, every second (for 5 seconds total), all nearby foes are Blinded for 3...7...8 seconds and take 10...22...25 damage. While activating this skill, you are easily interrupted. Dust Trap ends after 90 seconds.

components.m: a handful of fine sand

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d8} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Shields Up!
entries: Warn your allies of incoming ranged attacks, increasing their defense against them.

Choose any number of creatures that can hear you within range. For the duration, whenever a target takes damage from a ranged weapon attack, you can roll {@dice 2d6} and subtract the number rolled from the damage.
"Shields Up!"
Shout. For 5...10...11 seconds, you and all party members within earshot gain +60 armor against incoming projectile attacks.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the number subtracted increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Ether Lord
entries: Sheath yourself in woven ether, donning the robes of an ether lord, elevating your spellcasting to new heights, at a cost.
You lose all 1st level, and lower, spell slots.
For the duration, 1st level and lower spells do not require spell slots.

{@bold Enchantment.} Treat this spell as if you were maintaining {@status concentration} on it, except that it does not break {@status concentration} of other {@status concentration} spells when cast, nor does it break {@status concentration} on itself when other {@status concentration} spells are cast.
Ether Lord
Hex Spell. You lose all Energy. For 5...9...10 seconds, target foe suffers -1...3...3 Energy degeneration, and you experience +1...3...3 Energy regeneration.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the level of the spells and spell slots each increases by 1 for every two slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Malaise
entries: Afflict yourself with a malaise and spread it to an enemy, corrupting their spellcasting.

Choose one creature that you can see within range. The target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save for the duration at the start of each of your turns, you take {@damage 1d4} necrotic damage. Additionally, for the duration, when the target expends a spell slot to cast a spell, roll a {@dice d20}. On a 10 or lower, the spell expends an additional spell slot. If an additional spell slot is expended this way, this spell ends and the target takes {@damage 1d10} necrotic damage.

{@bold Hex.} Treat this spell as if you were maintaining {@status concentration} on it, except that it does not break {@status concentration} of other {@status concentration} spells when cast, nor does it break {@status concentration} on itself when other {@status concentration} spells are cast.
Malaise

Hex Spell. For 5...29...35 seconds, target foe suffers -1 Energy degeneration and you suffer -1 Health degeneration. If target foe's Energy reaches 0, that foe takes 5...41...50 damage and Malaise ends.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d10} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Swirling Aura
entries: Envelop yourself in a watery aura, regaining health every turn and increasing your defense against projectiles.
For the duration, at the start of each of your turns, you regain hit points equal to {@dice 2d6}. Additionally, for the duration, you have a +5 bonus to AC against ranged weapon attacks.
{@bold While Overcast.} Choose any number of friendly creatures that you can see within 150-feet. A target also gains the effect of this spell.

{@bold Enchantment.} Treat this spell as if you were maintaining {@status concentration} on it, except that it does not break {@status concentration} of other {@status concentration} spells when cast, nor does it break {@status concentration} on itself when other {@status concentration} spells are cast.
Swirling Aura

Enchantment Spell. For 5 seconds, you are enchanted with Swirling Aura and have 1...5...6 Health regeneration and a 50% chance to block projectiles. If you are Overcast when you cast this spell, all party members in earshot are also enchanted.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the healing increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Guilt
entries: Worm yourself into the consciousness of a creature by inducing an intense feeling of guilt.

Choose one creature that you can see within range. The target must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, for the duration, the next time the target casts a spell that targets an enemy of theirs, the spell fails and has no effect, the target's next initiative roll gets reduced by {@dice 4d8}, and your next initiative roll gets increased by the initiative lost.

{@bold Hex.} Treat this spell as if you were maintaining {@status concentration} on it, except that it does not break {@status concentration} of other {@status concentration} spells when cast, nor does it break {@status concentration} on itself when other {@status concentration} spells are cast.
Guilt
Hex Spell. For 6 seconds, the next time target foe casts a spell that targets a foe, the spell fails and you steal up to 5...12...14 Energy from that foe.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the reduction of initiative increases by {@dice 1d8} for each slot level above 3rd.

background.name: Ascalon
entries: Once, Ascalon was a beautiful, fertile land of rolling green countryside and magnificent cities. Her people were viewed as grim by their neighbors. This was perhaps, to be expected, given their never-ending war against the aggressive Charr. Indeed, it was their unfailing vigilance, their Great Northern Wall, and the blood they shed each year to defend it that had protected not only Ascalon, but also Kryta and Orr through the ages.
Then came the invasion, and with it, the Searing.

Anyone alive today will remember the day the lands of Ascalon were blasted and torn with magic fire. Whole cities and guilds were destroyed in the Searing, and the might of Ascalon was shattered. Now the Great Northern Wall lies broken, and the Charr have overrun much of the kingdom, defiling it with their unholy shrines, killing those who stand in their way.

The survival of Ascalon hinges on but a single remaining corner of the fallen kingdom—the capital city of Rin. In the final years of the last Guild War, the people of Rin looked to a soldier named Adelbern, a simple man of humble origins, who rallied the people with his courage and cunning and steeled them not only against the guilds of Orr and Kryta but also against the terrors of the Charr.

The sudden destruction of most of the kingdom during the Searing has taken much of the fight out of the man now known as King Adelbern. He has become stubborn and set in his ways, afraid of losing what little he has left. But in his son Rurik, the people see a leader with the courage to perhaps help them reclaim their fallen kingdom.

The survivors of Ascalon live in a state of constant warfare, using hit-and-run tactics and the remnants of the Great Wall to prevent any significant advances by the Charr into their territory. King Adelbern has circled the wagons, so to speak, content to simply defend what Ascalon has left and live to fight another day. Prince Rurik, on the other hand, is far more daring than his father thinks is wise, and has even suggested that the time may be coming to launch an offensive against the Charr.

Already the rumbling of the winds of change can be heard in the streets. People are frightened. They wonder what will become of them. Some even wonder aloud if Adelbern has lost what it takes to steer Ascalon back from the brink. They wish to see the prince step up and take command of the kingdom. Perhaps under his guidance, the people of Ascalon will live on to see another golden age.

background.name: Air Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Elementalist skills, especially spells that deal lightning damage to and debilitate a single enemy, become more effective with higher Air Magic.

background.name: Assassin
entries: The Assassin walks the shadows, a deadly viper ready to strike at the heart when the enemy least expects it, nowhere and everywhere all at once. Assassins are masters of their chosen weapon, the dagger, and are expert at inflicting Critical Strikes that cause massive damage. The Assassin is trained to efficiently link attacks together in a chain that does not give the enemy a chance to hit back. They have mastered the ability to move as shadows—Assassins wear only lightweight armor and prefer to avoid damage by not being there when the enemy’s strike lands. Their other magical skills include Hexes that lower the target’s defenses and protect the Assassin from harm.

background.name: Axe Mastery
entries: Axe Mastery increases the damage you do with axes and your chance to inflict a critical hit when using an axe. Many skills, especially axe attack skills become more effective with higher Axe Mastery.

background.name: Beast Mastery
entries: Beast Mastery increases the damage dealt by your animal companion and its chance to inflict a critical hit. Many Ranger skills, especially those related to making your animal companion stronger, become more effective with higher Beast Mastery.

background.name: Blood Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Necromancer skills, especially spells that damage and steal health from your foes, become more effective with higher Blood Magic.

background.name: Channeling Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Ritualist skills, especially those related to lightning damage and Energy, become more effective with higher Channeling Magic.

background.name: Charr Homelands
entries: The Charr Homelands lie to the north of Ascalon and, as the name implies, is the current homeland of the Charr. Its geography is much like how Ascalon was before the Searing and is home to Grawl, Skale, Worms, and a variety of Devourers among other creatures. Its true name is unknown.
The Elder Dragon Kralkatorrik can be seen sleeping in the center of this region, between the three explorable areas.

background.name: Command
entries: No inherent effect. Many Paragon skills, especially those that protect your allies or increase your tactical position on the battlefield, become more effective with higher Command.

background.name: Communing
entries: No inherent effect. Many Ritualist skills, especially those related to summoning Spirits, become more effective with higher Communing.

background.name: Critical Strikes
entries: For each rank of Critical Strikes you have, you gain an additional 1% chance to critical hit. Whenever you critical hit, you gain 1 energy at ranks 3 and above, 2 energy at ranks 8 and above, and 3 energy at 13 ranks above.

background.name: Crystal Desert
entries: Legends tell of a time, thousands of years ago, when the Crystal Desert was covered in water. These legends claim that it was the gods who raised the land, leaving it bare and empty in order to give the solitary creatures of the world a place to call their own. If the legends are true, humans were not among those for whom this land was made. There have been attempts by humans to settle in the desert, but they have, without exception, failed miserably, leaving behind only the grand monuments they built here proclaiming their short-lived triumph over this harsh land.

The weather in the Crystal Desert is hot and unforgiving. The winds blow hard, making and unmaking dunes, covering up the present and uncovering the past. An examination of the sand will reveal that each grain is actually a tiny, pointed crystal. In isolated locations, larger crystal formations have been revealed by the constant, unforgiving wind.

background.name: Curses
entries: No inherent effect. Many Necromancer skills, especially Hex spells which reduce your foes' effectiveness in battle, become more effective with higher Curses.

background.name: Dagger Mastery
entries: Dagger Mastery increases the damage you do with daggers and your chance to inflict a critical hit when using a dagger. There is a 2% chance per rank of Dagger Mastery that attacks from your daggers will double strike. Many skills, especially dagger attack skills, become more effective with higher Dagger Mastery.

background.name: Deadly Arts
entries: No Inherent effect. Many Assassins skills, especially those related to harming enemies, become more effective with higher Deadly Arts.

background.name: Death Magic
entries: Without Death Magic, you can control no more than two undead servants. For every two ranks of Death Magic, you can control one additional undead servant. Many Necromancer skills, especially those that animate undead servants, manipulate corpses, and deal cold damage, become more effective with higher Death Magic.

background.name: The Desolation
entries: The Desolation is situated on the northwestern portion of Elona, connected to the Crystal Desert. It is one of the most hostile regions on Tyria due to its sulfurous sands. It is riddled with poisonous sulfur deserts and is home to many undead creatures and the great Junundu wurms. The land was once under the rule of Palawa Joko but following his imprisonment the undead armies have gone through schisms and formed smaller groups.

The Desolation was once the coast of the Crystal Sea, and described as being a 'valley of verdant growth.' It was here that Abaddon was cast down by the other gods and banished into the Realm of Torment. His fall shattered and poisoned the land, turning it into what it is now. As the place where he was cast down, the Desolation is the part of Tyria closest to the Realm of Torment and it has begun to leak through and twist the already damaged lands.

background.name: Divine Favor
entries: For each rank of Divine Favor, allies are healed for 3.2 whenever you cast Monk spells on them. Several Monk skills, especially spells related to Energy gain and healing, become more effective with higher Divine Favor.

background.name: Domination Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Mesmer skills, especially spells that disrupt spell-casting and deal direct damage, become more effective with higher Domination Magic.

background.name: Earth Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Elementalist skills, especially spells that protect you and your allies or deal earth damage, become more effective with higher Earth Magic.

background.name: Earth Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Dervish Spells, especially those dealing with defense or Earth damage, become more effective with higher Earth Prayers.

background.name: Elementalist
entries: Elementalists summon the powers of earth, air, fire, and water and command them at will. They can inflict more damage in a single strike than any other profession. Earth Magic summons quakes and eruptions, encases enemies in stone, or protects allies. Air Magic harnesses the power of tempests to strike foes down with lightning or enable allies to run like the wind. Fire Magic manifests flames, fireballs, molten lava, and even meteors to burn enemies to a crisp. Water Magic conjures mist and ice to slow enemy movement and attacks, blur vision, protect allies against magic, and inflict cold damage on enemies. Elementalists have access to Energy regenerating skills, and when chosen as a primary character, they can increase their maximum Energy over time. The wise Elementalist avoids becoming surrounded, but keeps a local area-of-effect spell on hand just in case.

background.name: Elite
entries: Elite skills are skill types that have been specially designated by the designers as being more significant than non-elites. Players may only include one elite skill in their build. However, under special circumstances, a skill bar might have several Elites and this is explained below in copying Elite Skills.

Elite skills are meant to have powerful effects. Many builds are often constructed around (and named after) their elite skill. The choice of this type build leads to many of the remaining skill choices. A few examples of such elite skill-based builds include Barrage Ranger, Spiteful Spirit Necromancer, Healer's Boon Monk, Vow of Strength Dervish, Signet of Spirits Ritualist, Crippling Shot Ranger or Panic Mesmer.

background.name: Energy Storage
entries: For each rank of Energy Storage, your maximum Energy raises by 3. Several skills related to gaining Health or Energy become more effective with higher Energy Storage.

background.name: Expertise
entries: For each rank of Expertise, the Energy cost of all of your attacks, Rituals, touch skills and Rangers [sic] skills are decreased by 4%. Several skills, especially those related to Energy costs and skill recharge times, become more effective with higher Expertise.

background.name: Fast Casting
entries: Fast Casting decreases the activation time of your Spells and Signets. (No effect for non-Mesmer skills with an activation time less than 2 seconds.) In PvE, each rank of Fast Casting decreases the recharge time for your Mesmer Spells by 3%.

background.name: Fire Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Elementalist skills, especially spells that burn your foes or deal fire damage in large areas, become more effective with higher Fire Magic.

background.name: Hammer Mastery
entries: Hammer Mastery increases the damage you do with hammers and your chance to inflict a critical hit when using a hammer. Many skills, especially hammer attack skills become more effective with higher Hammer Mastery.

background.name: Healing Prayers
entries: No inherent effect. Many Monk skills, especially spells related to healing, become more effective with higher Healing Prayers.

background.name: Illusion Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Mesmer skills, especially spells that deceive your foes and hinder their movement and attacks, become more effective with higher Illusion Magic.

background.name: Inspiration Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Mesmer skills, especially spells that generate energy and reduce damage, become more effective with higher Inspiration Magic.

background.name: Kaineng City
entries: Kaineng City is the capital of the Empire of the Dragon. It is a huge metropolis that covers a large portion of northwestern Cantha. 'Kaineng' is Old Canthan for 'Emperor', giving the city the name of 'Emperor City.'

background.name: Kourna
entries: The province of Kourna is eternally ready for war. Military historians analyze the great battles that have taken place here: the epic conflicts of Primeval Kings, the desperate efforts to unite the land in the Shattered Dynasty Era, and of course, Turai Ossa’s defeat of Palawa Joko near the Grand Cataract at Jahai. For centuries, Kourna has had a military government, and its leaders have been direct descendents of Warmarshal Turai Ossa. Inspired by his example, Kournans revere loyalty, patriotism, a strong sense of duty, and dedication to military service. Not every Kournan is a soldier, but farmers laboring in the fields and crafters slaving in workshops know the value of a safe and secure province. The strength of the state depends on loyalty to its leaders. Pacified Centaur laborers add to the province’s muscle. Typical Kournan dedication drives citizens to work hard for prosperity—in fact, the entire nation relies on the province’s agriculture and handiwork. Kournan adventurers go to war secure in the knowledge that their swords are well-tempered and their armor well-made, forged as surely as the soldiers who wield them.

background.name: Leadership
entries: You gain 2 Energy for each ally affected by one of your Shouts or Chants (maximum 1 Energy for every 2 ranks).

background.name: Maguuma Jungle
entries: Years ago, many tribes of human druids lived among the Maguuma's lush greenery and wildlife. But it has been a long time since anyone has heard word from them, and many believe that they were eaten by hostile jungle creatures or simply swallowed whole by the man-eating plants now rampant in the jungle.

The higher elevations are mostly devoid of water. Only the largest and hardiest of plants can live here. But down farther, closer to the water table, the Maguuma grows thick. The vegetation can become so dense that there are areas of the jungle floor that have never been touched by the sun's light.

background.name: Marksmanship
entries: Marksmanship increases the damage you do with bows and your chance to inflict a critical hit when using a bow. Many Ranger skills, especially bow attack skills, become more effective with higher Marksmanship.

background.name: Mesmer
entries: Mesmers are masters of illusion and control, subverting the enemy’s Energy for their own use, and that of their allies. Combined with any other profession, their skills provide excellent support, turning enemies’ powers against them and changing the very fabric of reality to hinder foes and help allies. Mesmers have the ability to cast spells quickly, which can make all the difference in the heat of battle. Their powers of domination allow them to take control of enemy skills and Energy. Their unique illusionary talents can slow or even halt enemy movement and skill casting, or cause imaginary illnesses that drain Health and Energy from foes while healing and energizing allies. While Mesmers are not known for brute strength, their ability to confuse, distract, and drain the enemy’s resources more than compensates.

background.name: Monk
entries: Monks employ a direct conduit to the gods, and the answers to their prayers come in the form of healing and protection for their allies and damage to their enemies. Combined with any other profession, Monks can alternate between supporting their party and dealing damage to opponents. Monks enjoy Divine Favor, which provides extra healing power, while their healing and Protection Prayers help to keep their allies strong and healthy. Smiting Prayers, on the other hand, call down divine anger on enemies, exacting holy damage that ignores armor, though damage-dealing is not the Monk’s specialty. What Monks lack in firepower they make up for with their unparalleled gift for keeping their allies alive.

background.name: Motivation
entries: No inherent effect. Many Paragon skills, especially those related to Energy management or that inspire your allies, become more effective with higher Motivation.

background.name: Motivation
entries: Each rank in Mysticism reduces the cost of your Dervish enchantments by 4%. In PvE, you have +1 armor per rank of Mysticism while you are enchanted.

background.name: Necromancer
entries: Necromancers , calling on the spirits of the dead, and even death itself, to overpower enemies and assist allies. In sacrificing Health and taking curses and diseases upon themselves, they can deal large amounts of damage to those foolish enough to oppose them. Dead and dying enemies become unwilling allies in their hands. Necromancers have the singular ability to absorb Energy from an enemy’s death, and can raise a fighting force from the corpses of their foes. Curses, which often cost the Necromancer dearly, exact an even greater toll from enemies, who find that their Enchantments and healing skills are rendered useless. Due to the sacrificial nature of their methods, Necromancers must practice patience and self-discipline to survive.

background.name: No Attribute
entries: No Attribute skills are those which are not tied to a particular attribute. Effects of these unlinked skills are almost always constant; for example, Remove Hex always removes a single hex, whereas the Protection Prayers spell, Divert Hexes removes 1...3...3 hexes, depending on the caster's rank in that attribute.

background.name: No Profession
entries: No Attribute skills are those which are not tied to a particular profession.

background.name: Northeastern Kryta
entries: There are two types of humans in Kryta: those who worship the mysterious Unseen Ones and those who do not. The worshippers have become known as the White Mantle because of the long white sleeveless robes many of them wear.

It is the responsibility of the White Mantle to oversee the other humans and impose upon them the rules and laws of the Unseen Ones. Those inside the organization receive special privileges (more food, better clothing, access to books) simply for abiding by the rules of the Unseen Ones and carrying out the orders handed down by the White Mantle high priest. To the Krytans the White Mantle are the root of law and order, the protectors or saviors, if you will, of their lands.

The White Mantle maintain a series of temples all over the continent. Members of this organization frequently, though not always, choose to reside in these temples to better perform their duties to the Mantle and to more effectively worship the Unseen Ones.

Since the end of the last Guild War and the repelling of the Charr invasion, the White Mantle have maintained a high level of military preparedness. They don’t ever want to be caught off guard again, and they often keep large stores of weapons inside their temples to use in case of emergency. It’s also not uncommon for followers of the Mantle philosophy to be highly trained warriors. Fighting skills will come in handy if the day comes when they will need to once again defend Kryta from invasion.

background.name: Southwestern Kryta
entries: There are two types of humans in Kryta: those who worship the mysterious Unseen Ones and those who do not. The worshippers have become known as the White Mantle because of the long white sleeveless robes many of them wear.

It is the responsibility of the White Mantle to oversee the other humans and impose upon them the rules and laws of the Unseen Ones. Those inside the organization receive special privileges (more food, better clothing, access to books) simply for abiding by the rules of the Unseen Ones and carrying out the orders handed down by the White Mantle high priest. To the Krytans the White Mantle are the root of law and order, the protectors or saviors, if you will, of their lands.

The White Mantle maintain a series of temples all over the continent. Members of this organization frequently, though not always, choose to reside in these temples to better perform their duties to the Mantle and to more effectively worship the Unseen Ones.

Since the end of the last Guild War and the repelling of the Charr invasion, the White Mantle have maintained a high level of military preparedness. They don’t ever want to be caught off guard again, and they often keep large stores of weapons inside their temples to use in case of emergency. It’s also not uncommon for followers of the Mantle philosophy to be highly trained warriors. Fighting skills will come in handy if the day comes when they will need to once again defend Kryta from invasion.

background.name: Northern Shiverpeaks
entries: The Northern Shiverpeaks are, despite the name, a central region within the Shiverpeak Mountains. Inhabited mainly by the Deldrimor and Stone Summit Dwarves, they are also occupied by Centaurs and Ettins. They are often used as the primary route to cross the Shiverpeaks, with the Frost Gate barring one of two passes. There are few to no primary Deldrimor settlements in the Northern Shiverpeaks, but the Stone Summit are known to have mines here.

background.name: Pre-Searing
entries: Once, Ascalon was a beautiful, fertile land of rolling green countryside and magnificent cities. Her people were viewed as a bit grim by their neighbors, but this was perhaps to be expected, given their never-ending war against the Charr. Indeed, it was their unfailing vigilance, their Great Northern Wall, and the blood they shed each year to defend it that had protected not only Ascalon, but also Kryta and Orr through the ages.

background.name: Protection Prayers
entries: No inherent effect. Many monk skills, especially Enchantments that prevent damage or provide healing, become more effective with higher Protection Prayers.

background.name: Ranger
entries: Rangers are unique in their ability to succeed with the help of, or even in spite of, their environment. Nature rituals allow them to manipulate the environment to hinder their enemies, or borrow the very power of creation to heal and aid their allies. They favor long-range combat, the bow being their weapon of choice, and can be especially effective from elevated locations such as bridges and cliffs. They are the only profession with the ability to charm animals, which then accompany them on their travels and assist them in battle, gaining experience and levels over time. Rangers are also blessed with survival skills that help keep them alive by causing regeneration of health.

background.name: Restoration Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Ritualist skills, especially those related to healing, life-stealing, and defense, become more effective with higher Restoration Magic.

background.name: Ring of Fire Islands
entries: Just south of the Tarnished Coast lie the volcanic islands that together make up the Ring of Fire. The large volcano at the center of the ring is where the gods reportedly dropped the Bloodstones before leaving Tyria for good. Of the islands that surround this one, many are still active. Ships that pass by the Ring report hearing the tell-tale hiss of scalding hot lava hitting the ocean, instantly vaporizing the saltwater into steam.

The reefs off the islands are formed of black pumice stone. There are very few natural ports, and those that might be suitable for docking would bring the crew of the ship within danger of being caught by a sudden, unexpected eruption.
There are no known settlements in the Ring of Fire.

background.name: Scythe Mastery
entries: Scythe Mastery increases the damage you do with scythes and your chance to inflict a critical hit when using a scythe. Many skills, especially scythe attack skills, become more effective with higher Scythe Mastery.

background.name: Shadow Arts
entries: No inherent effect. Many Assassin skills, especially those related to defense and moving as a shadow, become more effective with higher Shadow Arts.

background.name: Shing Jea Island
entries: Shing Jea Island lies to the west of the Canthan mainland, southwest across the sea from Kaineng City. It is an idyllic place with farming and fishing settlements sparsely dotting the rural countryside. The primary population centers include Shing Jea Monastery and Seitung Harbor; the former being a center for profession training and latter the primary docks and center of trade for the island.

background.name: Smiting Prayers
entries: No inherent effect. Many Monk skills, especially those related to dealing holy damage, become more effective with higher Smiting Prayers. Holy damage is especially powerful against the undead.

background.name: Soul Reaping
entries: For each point of Soul Reaping, you gain 1 Energy whenever a non-Spirit creature near you dies. You may only gain Energy in this way 3 times every 15 seconds.

background.name: Southern Shiverpeaks
entries: The Southern Shiverpeaks is, as the name implies, southern portion of the Shiverpeak Mountains and home to the capital of the Dwarves. In contrast to the Northern Shiverpeaks, this segment of the mountain range is considerably harsher. All kinds of wildlife, such as Tundra Giants, Frost Wurms, Ice Imps, Blessed Griffons, and Mountain Trolls, roam the snowy tundra, and, in addition to Deldrimor and the Stone Summit, it is currently occupied by other warring factions: the Avicara Tengu, White Mantle, Shining Blade, and Mursaat. The northern and southern areas are connected by several long, winding, and treacherous valleys, heavily populated with dangerous indigenous creatures.

background.name: Spawning Power
entries: For each rank of Spawning Power you have, creatures you create (or animate) have 4% more Health, and weapon Spells you cast last 4% longer. Some Ritualist skills, especially those related to Spirit creatures, become more effective with higher Spawning Power.

background.name: Spear Mastery
entries: Spear Mastery increases the damage you do with spears and your chance to inflict a critical hit when using a spear. Many skills, especially spear attack skills, become more effective with higher Spear Mastery.

background.name: Strength
entries: When you use attack skills, each point of Strength gives you 1% armor penetration. Many skills, especially those related to surviving and inflicting damage, become more effective with higher Strength.

background.name: Swordsmanship
entries: Swordsmanship increases the damage you do with Swords and your chance to inflict a critical hit when using a sword. Many skills, especially sword attack skills become more effective with higher Swordsmanship.

background.name: Tactics
entries: No inherent effect. Many skills, especially defensive skills and skills that aid your allies, become more effective with higher Tactics.

background.name: Warrior
entries: Warriors rely on stout hearts, brute strength, and melee weapons to subdue their enemies and protect their allies. They generally disdain long-range warfare, preferring instead to charge directly into the fray swinging their weapon of choice. They can take a beating unlike anyone else. Warriors are equally comfortable wielding axe, hammer, or sword, though many choose to master one weapon over all others. Many Warrior skills require adrenaline, which builds up during combat to enable those skills, and usually results in major damage. Defensive tactics help the Warrior to avoid damage and protect allies, but Strength is the Warrior’s biggest asset, allowing this hero to do more damage with every attack.

background.name: Water Magic
entries: No inherent effect. Many Elementalist skills, especially spells that deal cold damage and slow or hinder your foes, become more effective with higher Water Magic.

background.name: Wilderness Survival
entries: No inherent effect. Many Ranger skills, especially Rituals, Preparations, and Traps, become more effective with higher Wilderness Survival.

background.name: Wind Prayers
entries: No inherent effect. Many Dervish Spells, especially those dealing with movement or cold damage, become more effective with higher Wind Prayers.

condition.name: Bleeding
entries: • A bleeding creature takes slashing damage at the start of each of its turns.
• The amount of slashing damage of the bleeding condition is determined by the effect that applied it.
• The condition can be ended early by regainig hit points.

condition.name: Burning
entries: • A burning creature takes fire damage at the start of each of its turns.
• The amount of fire damage of the burning condition is determined by the effect that applied it.
• The condition can be ended early by using an action to smother the flames.

condition.name: Cracked Armor
entries: • A creature with cracked armor has their AC reduced by 3.

condition.name: Crippled
entries: • A cripple creautre has their speed halved.

condition.name: Dazed
entries: • A dazed creature can't cast spells as reactions, must cast spells which take a bonus action as an action, and any other spell takes twice as long to cast.

condition.name: Deep Wound
entries: • A creautre with deep wound has their hit point maximum reduced by 20%.

condition.name: Disease
entries: • A diseased creature takes necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns.
• The amount of necrotic damage of the disease condition is determined by the effect that applied it.
• Any creature of the same creature type as the diseased creature that is within 5-feet of it when it starts its turn must succeed on a Constitution saving throw, or gain a copy of the condition.

condition.name: Overcast
entries: • An overcast creature temporarily loses access to spell slots equal to the remaining rounds, going from highest spell slot to lowest spell slot, regardless of if they have already been used.
• Further applications of overcast add to the existing duration.
• Spells which have the Overcast property gain additional effects when cast while having at least one round of overcast.

condition.name: Corruption
entries: • A corrupted creature takes poison damage at the start of each of its turns.
• The amount of poison damage of the corruption condition is determined by the effect that applied it.

condition.name: Weakness
entries: • A weakened creature deals only half damage with weapon attacks until the condition ends.

item.name: Light of Deldrimor
entries: The Light of Deldrimor is a legendary torch, said to have been forged by the Great Dwarf himself, when he forged the Dwarfs in Anvil Rock, to guide their way through the dark caves of the Shiverpeak Mountains.
The torch glows in a warm teal light.
As and action, a character holding the torch can ignite an object not being worn or carried within 5-feet of the wielder, transferring some of the warding magic.
Any creature friendly to the wielder within 10-feet of the Light of Deldrimor or any flame lit by it does not take damage from environmental cold effects.
While wielding the torch the following spells can be cast from it (fires ignited this way do not have the warding properties granted by the torch):
Cantrips (at will): {@spell Fire Bolt|PHB}, {@spell Control Flames|XGE}, {@spell Create Bonfire|XGE}, {@spell Produce Flame|PHB}

1st Level (1/day each): {@spell Burning Hands|PHB}, {@spell Chromatic Orb|PHB} (Fire), {@spell Faerie Fire|PHB}, {@spell Fire Storm (Guild Wars)|GuildWars}, {@spell Flare|GuildWars}, {@spell Hellish Rebuke|PHB}, {@spell Mind Burn|GuildWars}
2nd Level (1/day each): {@spell Aganazzar's Scorcher|XGE}, {@spell Continual Flame|PHB}, {@spell Inferno|GuildWars}, {@spell Fireball (Guild Wars)|GuildWars}
3rd Level (1/day each): {@spell Dispel Magic|PHB}, {@spell Fireball|PHB}, {@spell Immolate|GuildWars}
4th Level (2/day): {@spell Conjure Minor Elementals|PHB} ({@creature Azer|MM}), {@spell Fire Shield|PHB} (Warm), {@spell Phoenix|GuildWars}
5th Level (1/day): {@spell Meteor Shower|GuildWars}

item.name: Minaar's Explosive
entries: As an action, a character can throw a grenade at a point up to 60 feet away.

Each creature within a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 18 (4d8) thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
These grapefruit-sized bombs are the signature explosive used by Minaar Stonesledge, explosive expert of the Deldrimor dwarfs.

item.name: Minaar's Upgraded Explosive
entries: As an action, a character can throw a grenade at a point up to 60 feet away.

Each creature within a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 18 (4d8) thunder damage and 18 (4d8) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Enhanced by the infernal magics of the flame legion, Minaar's Explosive have reached a new level of destructive capability.

item.name: Potion of Arcane Recovery
entries: You regain {@damage 1d4} spell slots when you drink this potion.
The potion's blue liquid crackles with arcane energy.

item.name: Abaddon's Reach (Exalted)
entries: This longsword has a hilt which is in the shape of a mask with 6 eye slits, and tentacles coming out of it's back, making up the pommel.
'Act with magic, act within reason, act without mercy.' is inscribed on the blade.
You can use Abaddon's Reach as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Abaddon's Reach is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• You gain a +1 bonus to your charisma ability score.
• When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 psychic damage.

• You gain an additional volatile 3rd level spell slot. Immediately after you cast a spell using that spell slot, roll a d20. If you roll a 1, roll on the Wild Magic Surge table to create a random magical effect, otherwise the number you need to roll increases by 1, until you trigger a roll on the Wild Magic Surge table, at which point it will reset to 1. A Wild Magic Surge can happen once per turn. You regain this spell slot when you finish a short or long rest.
{@bold Awakened.} When Abaddon's Reach reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
• You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
• The extra psychic damage dealt by the weapon increases to 2d6.
• The level of your additional spell slot increases to 5th level.
{@bold Exalted.} When Abaddon's Reach reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +2.
• The extra psychic dealt by the weapon increases to 3d6.
• The level of your additional spell slot increases to 7th level.

item.name: Abaddon's Reach (Dormant)
entries: This longsword has a hilt which is in the shape of a mask with 6 eye slits, and tentacles coming out of it's back, making up the pommel.
'Act with magic, act within reason, act without mercy.' is inscribed on the blade.
You can use Abaddon's Reach as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Abaddon's Reach is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• You gain a +1 bonus to your charisma ability score.
• When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 psychic damage.

• You gain an additional volatile 3rd level spell slot. Immediately after you cast a spell using that spell slot, roll a d20. If you roll a 1, roll on the Wild Magic Surge table to create a random magical effect, otherwise the number you need to roll increases by 1, until you trigger a roll on the Wild Magic Surge table, at which point it will reset to 1. A Wild Magic Surge can happen once per turn. You regain this spell slot when you finish a short or long rest.

item.name: Seeker (Exalted)
entries: This light crossbow is in the shape of a dragon's wing.
'Tyria's last hope rests on the unity of the races. The pooling of their strength. It is the only way.' is inscribed on the grip.
You can use Seeker as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Seeker is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
• When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d4 piercing damage.

• The first attack roll you make with this weapon each turn scores a critical hit on a 19 or 20, if your target is within 5 feet of an ally of yours. If another feature or trait already gives you an increased critical hit range, increase that range by one instead.
{@bold Awakened.} When Seeker reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
• The extra piercing damage dealt by the weapon increases to 2d4.

• The first attack roll you make with this weapon each turn scores a critical hit on a 19 or 20, if you attack with advantage. If another feature or trait already gives you an increased critical hit range, increase that range by one instead.
{@bold Exalted.} When Seeker reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +3.
• The extra piercing damage dealt by the weapon increases to 3d4.

• The first attack roll you make with this weapon each turn scores a critical hit on a 19 or 20, while you are concentrating on a spell. If another feature or trait already gives you an increased critical hit range, increase that range by one instead.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Brotherhood of the Dragon

item.name: Seeker (Dormant)
entries: This light crossbow is in the shape of a dragon's wing.
'Tyria's last hope rests on the unity of the races. The pooling of their strength. It is the only way.' is inscribed on the grip.
You can use Seeker as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Seeker is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
• When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d4 piercing damage.

• The first attack roll you make with this weapon each turn scores a critical hit on a 19 or 20, if your target is within 5 feet of an ally of yours. If another feature or trait already gives you an increased critical hit range, increase that range by one instead.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Brotherhood of the Dragon

item.name: The Core (Exalted)
entries: This flaming greatsword is made of ornamented deldrimor steel, with a heavy core of infernal iron.
'Offer protection to the weak. Give solace and shelter to those who need it. Be ye a salve to the wounded.' is inscribed on the blade.
You can use The Core as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While The Core is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
• When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 fire damage.

• On your turn, when you score a critical hit against a creature with The Core or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with it, you gain temporary hit points equal to the challenge rating of the creature or your proficiency bonus, whichever is higher.
{@bold Awakened.} When The Core reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
• The extra fire damage dealt by the weapon increases to 2d6.

• On your turn, when you score a critical hit against a creature with The Core or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with it, you can cause flames to erupt, damaging creatures of you choice within 10 feet of you, equal to the challenge rating of the creature or your proficiency bonus, whichever is higher.
{@bold Exalted.} When The Core reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +3.
• The extra fire damage dealt by the weapon increases to 3d6.
• On your turn, when you score a critical hit against a creature with The Core or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with it, you can make one extra melee weapon attack as part of your attack action.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Core Warband

item.name: The Core (Dormant)
entries: This flaming greatsword is made of ornamented deldrimor steel, with a heavy core of infernal iron.
'Offer protection to the weak. Give solace and shelter to those who need it. Be ye a salve to the wounded.' is inscribed on the blade.
You can use The Core as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While The Core is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon.
• When you hit with an attack using this weapon, the target takes an extra 1d6 fire damage.

• On your turn, when you score a critical hit against a creature with The Core or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with it, you gain temporary hit points equal to the challenge rating of the creature or your proficiency bonus, whichever is higher.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Core Warband

item.name: Celestial Slicer (Exalted)
entries: This silver-bladed sickle glimmers softly with moonlight. When looking at the reflection on the blade you can see the night sky.
'Lead through actions, not words!' is inscribed on the silver blade.
You can use the Celestial Slicer as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
You can use the Celestial Slicer as a star map while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While the Celestial Slicer is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• When attacking with the Celestial Slicer you can use Wisdom instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls.
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
• You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.

• When you make ranged spell attack roll against a creature, you can target one additional creature and make a second attack roll against it. You can use this feature a number of times equal to you proficiency bonus and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
{@bold Awakened.} When the Celestial Slicer reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +2.

• If you cast a spell with a spell slot of 1st level or higher and target an ally with the spell, that ally can use their reaction immediately after the spell to make one weapon attack against a creature of your choice that you can see. If the spell targets more than one ally, you choose the ally who can make the attack.
{@bold Exalted.} When the Celestial Slicer reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +3.
• You can maintain concentration on two spells. When making a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration, make one for each concentration.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Ascalon Vanguard

item.name: Celestial Slicer (Dormant)
entries: This silver-bladed sickle glimmers softly with moonlight. When looking at the reflection on the blade you can see the night sky.
'Lead through actions, not words!' is inscribed on the silver blade.
You can use the Celestial Slicer as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
You can use the Celestial Slicer as a star map while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While the Celestial Slicer is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• When attacking with the Celestial Slicer you can use Wisdom instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls.
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
• You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.

• When you make ranged spell attack roll against a creature, you can target one additional creature and make a second attack roll against it. You can use this feature a number of times equal to you proficiency bonus and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Ascalon Vanguard

item.name: Incursion Breaker (Exalted)
entries: This staff is imbued with powerful arcane magic.
'Our gift to the people of Tyria is that they never know just how much danger they've been in.' is inscribed along the shaft of the staff.
You can use Incursion Breaker as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Incursion Breaker is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• When attacking with the Incursion Breaker you can use Intelligence instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls.
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
• You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.

• When you make ranged spell attack roll against a creature, you can give yourself advantage on that roll by taking force damage equal to the spells level (minimum 1) or if it wasn't a spell equal to your proficiency bonus.

• When you force a creature to make a saving throw to take half damage, you can take force damage equal to the spells level (minimum 1) or if it wasn't a spell equal to your proficiency bonus, to give one or more targets of the spell disadvantage on its first saving throw made against the spell. If you give multiple targets disadvantage you take force damage for each target.
{@bold Awakened.} When Incursion Breaker reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +2.
• You can add your proficiency bonus to one damage roll of any spell or class feature, that requires a ranged spell attack roll or forces a creature to make a saving throw.
{@bold Exalted.} When Incursion Breaker reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:
• The weapon's bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3.
• The bonus to spell attack rolls and your spell save DC increases to +3.

• You can deal maximum damage, instead of rolling for any spell or class feature, that requires a ranged spell attack roll or forces a creature to make a saving throw. You can use this feature a number of times equal to you proficiency bonus and regain all expended uses when you finish a short rest.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Wizard's Court

item.name: Incursion Breaker (Dormant)
entries: This staff is imbued with powerful arcane magic.
'Our gift to the people of Tyria is that they never know just how much danger they've been in.' is inscribed along the shaft of the staff.
You can use Incursion Breaker as a spellcasting focus for your spells while attuned to it.
{@bold Dormant.} While Incursion Breaker is in a dormant state, you gain the following benefits:
• When attacking with the Incursion Breaker you can use Intelligence instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls.
• You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
• You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and the saving throw DCs of your spells.

• When you make ranged spell attack roll against a creature, you can give yourself advantage on that roll by taking force damage equal to the spells level (minimum 1) or if it wasn't a spell equal to your proficiency bonus.

• When you force a creature to make a saving throw to take half damage, you can take force damage equal to the spells level (minimum 1) or if it wasn't a spell equal to your proficiency bonus, to give one or more targets of the spell disadvantage on its first saving throw made against the spell. If you give multiple targets disadvantage you take force damage for each target.
item.reqAttune: by a member of the Wizard's Court

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bone horror makes a number of Swipe attacks equal to half the level of the spell (rounded down) (minimum 1).

action.name: Swipe
entries: Natural Weapon: 3 + PB to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.
Bone Horrors are minions created by certain Necromancer skills (Animate Bone Horror, Malign Intervention, and Aura of the Lich) and the Minion Apocalypse Flux.

action.name: Cat's Claws
entries: You can use your claws to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with them, the strike deals {@dice 1d6} + your Strength/Dexterity modifier slashing damage, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

The Charr are aggressive, industrious, and wholly dedicated to becoming the pre-eminent species of Tyria. A savage race of sentient beasts, the Charr will use any means available to destroy their enemies: an ambush is as honorable as a fair fight, as victory is what matters. Though Charr have no concept of mercy, they can be protective of those within their tribe.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The Grasp of Chaos has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the Grasp of Chaos's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally doesn't have the {@condition incapacitated} condition.

action.name: Lunge
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit; reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 4d4 + 2}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 11} Strength saving throw or have the {@condition prone} condition.
Grasps of Chaos guard General Kahyet in the Blacktide Den mission. They are allied at first, then become hostile after a short dialogue.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Grasp of Chaos is a 2nd-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Dexterity (spell save {@dc 12}, +4 to hit with spell attacks). The Grasp of Chaos has the following Warrior (GW) spells prepared:

trait.name: Evasive Teleportation
entries: Whenever it takes damage or is the target of a ranged attack, the Oni can teleport, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, to an unoccupied space it can see within 20 feet of itself (no action required). If this effect is triggered by a ranged attack, the Oni teleports just before the attack hits, causing the attack to miss it. This trait is suppressed while the Oni has the {@condition incapacitated} condition.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Oni makes two Claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit; reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

There are some who say that the demonic, savage Oni originate in the Mists, others from someplace even more distant, dark, and cut off from the world of sanity. They are killers from beyond, appearing from nowhere to butcher their victims, for what reason no one knows. Whatever their purpose or origin, the Oni are among the most deadly things on two legs in Cantha.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Oni is a 5th-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). The Oni has the following Assassin (GW) spells prepared:

entries: Nature Rituals are a type of rituals unique to the ranger profession. These skills summon a spirit that provides a global effect to all those in its area of effect. Unlike Binding Rituals, Nature Rituals affect everyone in their range, enemies and allies alike.
The Nature Ritual spirits resemble miniature druids from the Maguuma Jungle and Melandru's Watcher, the avatar of Melandru, the patron goddess of rangers.

entries: Whiptail Devourer

Whiptail Devourers are common foes infesting the shattered countryside of Ascalon. They attack primarily by shooting projectiles with their tails. Like all devourers, they are often hidden beneath the surface of the ground, bursting from their hiding place to ambush unsuspecting prey.

trait.name: Assassinate
entries: During its first turn, the whiptail devourer has advantage on attack rolls against any creature that hasn't taken a turn. Any hit the whiptail devourer scores against a {@quickref Surprise|PHB|3|0|surprised} creature is a critical hit.

trait.name: Chameleon Skin
entries: The whiptail devourer has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide.

trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The whiptail devourer can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the whiptail devourer doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Whiptail Devourer can make two attacks it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Stinger Launch
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 90/150 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

entries: Carrion Devourer
Carrion Devourers are common hardy dangers found in the wild countryside of Ascalon, both before and after the Searing.

Plague Devourer

Plague Devourers are hardy natural dangers that infest the countryside of Ascalon, both before and after the Searing, although they have become much more common since the Searing. Like all devourers, they are often hidden beneath the surface of the ground, bursting from their hiding place to ambush unsuspecting prey.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Hydra (Ascalon) makes as many bite attacks as it has heads.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) piercing damage.

trait.name: Multiple Heads (Hydra)
entries: The hydra (ascalon) has three heads. While it has more than one head, the hydra (ascalon) has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.
Whenever the hydra (ascalon) takes 25 or more damage in a single turn, one of its heads dies. If all its heads die, the hydra (ascalon) dies.

At the end of its turn, it grows two heads for each of its heads that died since its last turn, unless it has taken fire damage since its last turn. The hydra (ascalon) regains 10 hit points for each head regrown in this way.

trait.name: Reactive Heads (Hydra)
entries: For each head the hydra (ascalon) has beyond one, it gets an extra reaction that can be used only for opportunity attacks.

trait.name: Wakeful (Hydra)
entries: While the hydra (ascalon) sleeps, at least one of its heads is awake.

trait.name: Hold Breath (Hydra)
entries: The hydra (ascalon) can hold its breath for 1 hour.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Hydra (Ascalon) is a 10th-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). The Hydra (Ascalon) has the following Elementalist (GW) spells prepared:

entries: Hydras are large three-headed lizards that use potent Fire Magic. The Hydras in Ascalon are found in small groups of two to four, throughout the northwest territories of Post-Searing Ascalon. These groups tend to mingle with other indigenous enemies in these areas; for example, with Stone Furies and Boulder Elementals in the Ascalon Foothills, and Charr hunting bands in the Flame Temple Corridor. In the northern region of Dragon's Gullet, Hydra groups flock together in herds, forming lethal mobs when attacked.
Resurrect Gargoyle
Resurrect Gargoyles can be found in groups with Shatter Gargoyles and Flash Gargoyles.

trait.name: False Appearance (Gargoyle)
entries: While the resurrect gargoyle remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a inanimate statue.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Resurrect Gargoyle is a 3rd-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 9}, +1 to hit with spell attacks). The Resurrect Gargoyle has the following Monk (GW) spells prepared:

action.name: Fling Lightning
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 1} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d4 - 1}) lightning damage.

action.name: Resurrect
entries: Resurrect a party member from range, but at the cost of their actions next turn. Choose one friendly dead creature, which has not been dead for more than 1 minute, that you can see within range. That creature returns to life with 25% of their maximum hit points. The creature cannot take actions, bonus actions or reactions until the end of their next turn. This spell can't return to life a creature that has died of old age, nor can it restore any missing body parts.
Shatter Gargoyle
Shatter Gargoyles are found in the company of Flash Gargoyles and sometimes Resurrect Gargoyles.

entries: When the Grawl Ulodyte reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the Grawl Ulodyte can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make another attack.

headerEntries: The Grawl Ulodyte is a 3rd-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). The Grawl Ulodyte has the following Monk (GW) spells prepared:

entries: Grawl Ulodytes are the powerful shamans of the Grawl. In combat, they provide a lot of healing support for Grawl warriors. It may be difficult to defeat groups of Grawl if they have multiple Ulodytes.

action.name: Radiant Scepter
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 90/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) radiant damage.
Boulder Elemental
Boulder Elementals are melee fighter elementals that rely on brute force to fight.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Boulder Elemental is a 2nd-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Strength (spell save {@dc 14}, +6 to hit with spell attacks). The Boulder Elemental has the following Warrior (GW) spells prepared:

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Hurl Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30/90 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

reaction.name: Abaddon's Chosen
entries: Once per long rest, when the Margonite is below 50% of their hit point maximum, they can choose to become immune to all damage until the end of their next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Margonite Executioner can make three hammer attacks, it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Abaddon's Favor
entries: Once per long rest, the Margonite can choose one creature affected by Abaddon's Chosen, all creatures within 15 feet of that creature must succeed on a charisma saving throw or take {@damage 6d6} psychic damage. The target then regains hit points equal to the damage rolled.

action.name: Hammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage, or 23 ({@damage 3d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Margonite Executioner is a 7th-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Strength (spell save {@dc 19}, +11 to hit with spell attacks). The Margonite Executioner has the following Warrior (GW) spells prepared:

entries: Margonite Executioners provide the melee muscle in a Margonite group. While their damage output is weak for a warrior, they can weaken and knock down party members.
White Mantle Knights are the warriors of the White Mantle.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The White Mantle Knight is a 4th-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Strength (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). The White Mantle Knight has the following Warrior (GW) spells prepared:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The White Mantle Knight can make two sword attacks, it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Light Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage.

Justiciar Hablion was one of the few people who survived the Rise of the White Mantle, and thus one of the few people who could accurately describe the events of that night. He was one of Saul D'Alessio's closest allies up until his disappearance. He would later become a very high-ranking member of the White Mantle.

He first met the Ascalonian refugees at the Gates of Kryta, where they helped him clear the swamp of undead in exchange for asylum in Kryta. He would later encounter them again, giving them the Eye of Janthir to help them select the Chosen - they thought that they would be escorting them to the Temple of the Unseen, but in fact they were to be executed atop the Bloodstone. The Ascalonians learned of this and confronted Hablion, eventually slaying him atop the Bloodstone.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Justiciar Hablion is a 7th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Strength (spell save {@dc 19}, +11 to hit with spell attacks). Justiciar Hablion has the following Warrior (GW) spells prepared:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Justiciar Hablion can make four axe attacks, he can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Axe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Heavy Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Load Shot
entries: At initiative 20 the trebuchet loads either a boulder, gravel or fire shot.

action.name: Fire loaded Shot
entries: At initiative 10 the trebuchet fires the shot it loaded.

action.name: Boulder Shot
entries: Choose a point that you can see within range. Each creature in a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 22} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes {@damage 6d6} bludgeoning damage, is knocked {@condition prone}. On a successful save, a target takes half as much damage.

action.name: Gravel Shot
entries: Choose a point that you can see within range. Each creature in a 15-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a DC20 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes {@damage 4d6} bludgeoning damage and starts {@condition bleeding|GuildWars} for the duration, taking {@damage 2d4} damage. On a successful save, a target takes half as much damage.
At the end of each of its turns, a target can make a Constitution saving throw. On a success, the condition ends.

action.name: Fire Shot
entries: Choose a point that you can see within range. Each creature in a 30-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes {@damage 2d6} fire damage and starts {@condition burning|GuildWars} for the duration, taking {@damage 4d4} damage. On a successful save, a target takes half as much damage.
At the end of each of its turns, a target can make a Dexterity saving throw. On a success, the condition ends.

action.name: Reset
entries: At initiative 0 the trebuchet resets.

trait.name: Damage Threshold
entries: The trebuchet only takes damage if it took at least 10.

trait.name: Requires operation
entries: At least two creatures must use their action to operate the trebuchet for it to be able to load, fire and reset.
A trebuchet, a siege weapon similar to a catapult or ballista, is a stationary map object used to inflict large amounts of damage to those in its target zone.

trait.name: Arcane Barrier
entries: While channeling an Obelisk, the Mage has an AC of 15, 100 hit points and a damage threshold of 10.

trait.name: Channeling
entries: While channeling an Obelisk, the Mage's STR, DEX and CON score get replaced by the Obelisks.

action.name: Obelisk Lightning
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) lightning damage.

reaction.name: Discharge Arcane Lightning
entries: When a hostile creature enters the Mage's reach or start's its turn in range, the mage can use its Obelisk Lightning attack as a reaction.

bonus.name: Obelisk Lightning
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) lightning damage.
An Obelisk is a magical attack platform usually constructed with three upright pillars surrounding a central raised dais.

action.name: Cat's Claws
entries: You can use your claws to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with them, the strike deals {@dice 1d6} + your Strength/Dexterity modifier slashing damage, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

action.name: Flame Scepter
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 4d8 + 6}) fire damage.

Bonfaaz Burntfur is a powerful Charr chieftain and the leader of the Charr forces assaulting Ascalon. Players first encounter him in The Great Northern Wall mission as he prepares the Charr forces for an invasion of the areas of Ascalon south of the wall. Later on they encounter him in the Nolani Academy mission as he tried to capture the capital city of Rin.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting

footerEntries: *Bonfaaz Burntfur casts these spells on itself before combat.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Bonfaaz Burntfur fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

legendary.name: Move
entries: Bonfaaz Burntfur moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Cantrip
entries: Bonfaaz Burntfur casts a cantrip.

legendary.name: Overcharge Effigy (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Bonfaaz Burntfur chooses a titan effigy he can see and overcharges it, inspiring all charr within 60-feet of it. Each charr affected has advantage on their next attack roll, has their movement speed doubled for 1 round, and gains one additional action.

trait.name: Charge

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The centaur makes two attacks: one with its Pike and one with its hooves or two with its Longbow.

action.name: Hooves

action.name: Longbow

trait.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: They have advantage on saving throws against poison, and they have resistance to poison damage.

One of the oldest races on Tyria, the Dwarves are humanoids that are stocky, short, and are almost always bearded. The dwarves live in the Shiverpeak Mountains - specifically the Northern Shiverpeaks and the Southern Shiverpeaks.

In recent years, the dwarves have been plunged into a civil war between the older Deldrimor dwarves and the recent Stone Summit faction. This war has caused unrest throughout the Shiverpeaks and hold up most travel between Ascalon and the other human nations.

action.name: Warhammer

Deldrimor is a kingdom of dwarves residing in the Shiverpeak Mountains. They are very friendly towards other races, such as the humans, and passage through the harsh mountain range (which, along with the Sea of Sorrows divides the continent of Tyria in half) is welcome to anyone who is a friend of Deldrimor.

One of the oldest races on Tyria, the Dwarves are humanoids that are stocky, short, and are almost always bearded. The dwarves live in the Shiverpeak Mountains - specifically the Northern Shiverpeaks and the Southern Shiverpeaks.

In recent years, the dwarves have been plunged into a civil war between the older Deldrimor dwarves and the recent Stone Summit faction. This war has caused unrest throughout the Shiverpeaks and hold up most travel between Ascalon and the other human nations.

trait.name: Ethereal Sight
entries: The Spirit of the Fallen can see 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when it is on the Material Plane, and vice versa.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The Spirit of the Fallen can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Spectral Armor and Shield

action.name: Etherealness

trait.name: Demoinc Ancestry
entries: The Dryder has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}, and magic can't put the Dryder to sleep.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The Dryder can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the Dryder has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Web Walker
entries: The Dryder ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Dryder makes two attacks: two with its bite, it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4+4}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) necrotic damage.
Dryders are spider-like creatures that can be found throughout Tyria and the Mists.

They are almost exclusively offensive spellcasters, mostly encountered as hex-based necromancers throughout Tyria, and more frequently as elementalists and mesmers in The Mists, where they usually serve Dhuum.
They tend to prefer very cold or icy places, such as the Shiverpeaks mountains, or on the contrary extremely hot places, such as the Ring of Fire Islands.
They also seem to feed on souls as they are frequently seen next to dead bodies or souls, and their skills (Soul Leech, Soul Torture) further references that.
According to Nicholas the Traveler, Frostfire Dryders have poisonous fangs, however none of the Dryders in the game can actually inflict poison.

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The ice elemental can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

trait.name: Splinter
entries: A creature that hits the ice elemental with a melee weapon attack that deals bludgeoning damage while within 5 feet of the elemental takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) piercing damage as shards of ice fly out from the elemental's body.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Ice Golem makes two attacks: two with its Ice Claw, it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Ice Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Encase in Ice
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d6}) cold damage, and the target must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, ice begins to form around the creature, and it is {@condition restrained}. The {@condition restrained} creature must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn, becoming {@condition petrified} in ice on a failure or ending the effect on a success. The petrification lasts until the creature spends at least 1 hour in a warm environment. Alternatively, a creature can be freed of the {@condition restrained} or {@condition petrified} conditions if it takes at least 10 fire damage.

entries: Ice Golems are elementals made out of ice, constructed by the Dwarves of the Stone Summit to aid them in combat.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the minotaur moves at least 10 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 9 ({@damage 2d8}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 10 feet away and knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Tribal Recall
entries: The minotaur can perfectly recall any path it has traveled.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the minotaur can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

An old folk legend states the only reason Dolyaks were domesticated instead of minotaurs is because minotaurs would rather be beaten to death than obey a command. Dolyaks, simply put, were less stubborn. Minotaurs are one of the oldest species in Tyria and are very much prized by the Norn for their warm, furry coats. They were once extremely populous throughout the Shiverpeaks but now reside solely in the northern regions, where they have sheltered valleys and caves to make their homes.
