Juniper Barks are plant creatures that populate the Shiverpeak Mountains. They spend most of their time just below the surface of the ground, but pop up to attack when enemies come near. While not particularly dangerous by themselves, when they appear during a battle with other, more dangerous creatures, they cease to be a mere nuisance and become a true threat.

entries: Frostfire Dryder is a Dryder boss that appears in Iron Horse Mine.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The Frostfire Dryder Necromancer Boss moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Spellcasting
entries: The Frostfire Dryder Necromancer Boss uses Spellcasting.

legendary.name: Attack

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The ice elemental can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

trait.name: Splinter
entries: A creature that hits the ice elemental with a melee weapon attack that deals bludgeoning damage while within 5 feet of the elemental takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) piercing damage as shards of ice fly out from the elemental's body.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the ice golem boss fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Ice Golem makes two attacks: two with its Ice Claw, it can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Ice Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 5d8 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Encase in Ice
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}21 ({@damage 6d6}) cold damage, and the target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, ice begins to form around the creature, and it is {@condition restrained}. The {@condition restrained} creature must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn, becoming {@condition petrified} in ice on a failure or ending the effect on a success. The petrification lasts until the creature spends at least 1 hour in a warm environment. Alternatively, a creature can be freed of the {@condition restrained} or {@condition petrified} conditions if it takes at least 10 fire damage.

footerEntries: *The Ice Golem casts these spells on itself before combat.

entries: The Judge is an Elemental boss that appears in Traveler's Vale and Thunderhead Keep.

legendary.name: Spellcasting

legendary.name: Attack

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The imp can use its action to polymorph into a beast form that resembles a rat (speed 20 ft.), a raven (20 ft., fly 60 ft.), or a spider (20 ft., climb 20 ft.), or back into its true form. Its statistics are the same in each form, except for the speed changes noted. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the imp's darkvision.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The imp has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Sting (Bite in Beast Form)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 3d4 + 5}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking 24 ({@damage 7d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Invisibility
entries: The imp magically turns {@condition invisible} until it attacks, or until its {@status concentration} ends (as if {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell). Any equipment the imp wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with it.
Ice Imps are water elementalists found in Shiverpeak Mountains.

trait.name: Dwarven Fleet Foot
entries: When Minaar Stonesledge takes fire damage, her speed increases by 10 feet until the end of her next turn. In addition, she has advantage on her next initiative roll.

trait.name: Siege Expert
entries: Minaar Stonesledge deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Minaar Stonesledge makes two Wrecking Maul or Fire Blast attacks.

action.name: Wrecking Maul
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 15 feet away from Minaar Stonesledge and knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Fire Blast
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 5d6 + 3}) fire damage.

action.name: Combustion Wave {@recharge 5}
entries: Minaar Stonesledge slams her massive hammer into the ground, battering herself and its foes with a fiery shockwave. Each creature within 20 feet of Minaar Stonesledge, including herself, must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, taking 17 ({@damage 5d6}) fire damage and 17 ({@damage 5d6}) thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Creatures behind cover have advantage on the saving throw.

action.name: Thunder Bomb
entries: Minaar Stonesledge lights a grapefruit-sized bomb and throws it at a point up to 60 feet away, where it explodes. Each creature within a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. After Minaar Stonesledge throws the bomb, roll a {@dice d6}; on a roll of 4 or lower, Minaar Stonesledge has no more bombs to throw.

action.name: Thunder Bomb (Enhanced)
entries: Minaar Stonesledge lights a grapefruit-sized bomb and throws it at a point up to 60 feet away, where it explodes. Each creature within a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) thunder damage and 18 ({@damage 4d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. After Minaar Stonesledge throws the bomb, roll a {@dice d6}; on a roll of 4 or lower, Minaar Stonesledge has no more bombs to throw.

Minaar Stonesledge is a Deldrimor dwarf who has been captured by the Stone Summit and put to work in the Iron Horse Mine. While in captivity, he has heard about some Stone Summit plans for a new war machine, which become the focus of the quest Minaar's Worry.

reaction.name: Invoke the Great Dwarf.
entries: Once per day, if Minaar Stonesledge fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: King Jalis Ironhammer has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition poisoned}.

trait.name: Indomitable (2/Day)
entries: King Jalis Ironhammer can reroll a saving throw that he fails. He must use the new roll.

trait.name: Second Wind (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: As a bonus action, King Jalis Ironhammer can regain 20 hit points.

trait.name: Extra Damage
entries: If King Jalis Ironhammer has more than half his hit points remaining he deals an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) slashing damage on every hit.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The King Jalis Ironhammer makes three attacks: three with its Greataxe, he can forgo one of these attacks to cast a spell.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d12 + 5}) slashing damage

action.name: Heavy Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d10 + 2}) piercing damage.

The wise king of the Deldrimor dwarves, King Jalis Ironhammer rules his people from the peaks of the Shiverpeak mountains. He is a smart, strong, patient man who makes decisions based solely on how they will affect the well-being of all the dwarves in Deldrimor. He lives to serve his people, and they love and respect him for it.

There are those, however, who wish to see the good king taken out of power. Namely, the Stone Summit, a group of xenophobic dwarves who had broken their ties with Deldrimor and are trying to take control of the dwarven nation. Over the past several years, the Summit have been growing their power, and a civil war is brewing.

King Jalis Ironhammer does not want to fight other dwarves, but he will do what he must to keep his people safe. Along with his loyal brother, Brechnar Ironhammer, the king has rallied his forces, and they stand ready to defend their home. The question on the king's mind though is this: Can he win?

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: When the Volatile Ice Elemental, it explodes in a burst of jagged ice. Each creature within 5 feet of it must make a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw, taking 4 ({@damage 2d4}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the Volatile Ice Elemental remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary shard of ice.

action.name: Explode
entries: The Volatile Ice Elemental explodes, killing itself and empowering its Death Burst trait:
- The DC increases to {@dc 14}.
- The radius increases to 10 feet.
- The damage increases to 8 ({@damage 4d4}) cold damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Nicholas the Traveler is a 5th-level spellcaster. Their spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 14}, +6 to hit with spell attacks). Nicholas the Traveler has the following Warrior (GW) spells prepared:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The urban ranger makes two melee attacks or two ranged attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, ranged 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage.
Nicholas Sandford (born 1035 AE) is an Ascalonian traveler, a craftsman and a writer.

Nicholas met his dolyak friend, Professor Yakkington, during a snowstorm in the Northern Shiverpeaks. The two managed to survive by huddling together for warmth and they have been together ever since.

Due to the Searing, Nicholas lost his parents, friends and beloved Mary Malone. After having mourned in seclusion for years, his hair grown white, he started to travel the world and dropped his last name in favor of the moniker "the Traveler".
He has made many friends, including Gwen and Durmand, and is often seen collecting items to aid them (especially Durmand or Zinn) in some form, or catering to Yakkington's whims.

A true craftsman, Nicholas is able to make various tools and even small sculptures out of various items he finds. Once he helped Vael by making a disguise out of Quetzal Crests so Vael could spy on the Tengu of Cantha.
In exchange, he has gathered up a hefty supply of exotic and unique items to put in his Gifts of the Traveler, which he trades with adventurers in exchange for the items he needs.
Nicholas is very interested in local folklore, in fauna and flora. As a writer he has written a novel entitled "There with Yakkington: A Traveler's Tale.".

He also claims to be a gourmet chef, thanks to the various different foods he has tasted throughout his travels, which his friendship with Imperial Chef Yileng may suggest to be true, and a medic, as he is often seen trying to come up with some remedy to counteract various poisons (notably those inflicted by Dryders or Rot Wallows).

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the yak moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a ram attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@dice 2d6}) damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 4d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one {@condition prone} creature. {@h}18 ({@damage 6d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

Professor Yakkington (born in 1057 AE) is the companion of Nicholas Sandford the Traveler. He was found by Nicholas during a blizzard in Traveler's Vale, having been abandoned by his mother like most young Dolyaks perceived to be weak. After using each other for warmth in the blizzard, Yakkington has joined Nicholas in his travels across Tyria.

In their travels, Yakkington is the fighter of the pair, holding back the wildlife for Nick. He also has a good sense of smell which comes in handy when trying to find their path again should they get lost.

Since his travels, Yakkington has become pampered by Nicholas, and often becomes stubborn. He enjoys having daily sweets and eating Red Iris Flowers, but has a strong fear of snakes and darkness. Because of his fears, Nick often puts Enchanted Lodestones to act as lights at night when Yakkington sleeps. According to Nick, he is 6'8", weighs about a ton, and his lucky number is 5.

action.name: Javelin

Pitney was a farmer whose field was plagued by worms and resided in Ashford. After the Searing, he has joined the Ascalon Army wanting revenge on the Charr.

action.name: Overwhelming Revelation {@recharge 5}

Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 45 ({@damage 10d8}) psychic damage and is {@condition stunned} until the end of the diviner's next turn. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition stunned}.

reaction.name: Portent (3/Day)

Mother of Ivy the Rabbit Slayer  (Web view) and Ben  (Web view), wife of Sven  (Web view).
A part of a group that went north off the wall, the group she is a part of is still missing.
Have been missing for the last three months, were supposed to be back four months ago.
Hope is that they had to take a longer route back.  Fear is that they are dead or captured.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The ursan transformation has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

action.name: Ursan Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Ursan Rage {@recharge 5}
entries: Choose one creature that you can see within 5-feet of you. Target each creature other than you in a 5-foot-radius centered on the target. Make a melee attack against each target. On a hit, a target takes {@damage 3d6 + 4} slashing damage and must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, a target is knocked {@condition prone}.

bonus.name: Ursan Force {@recharge 4}
entries: For 3 rounds, your speed is increased by 10 feet, and you cannot be knocked {@condition prone}.

bonus.name: Ursan Roar {@recharge}
entries: Choose any number of friendly creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. For 1 round, the next time a target hits with a weapon attack, they deal an additional {@damage 1d6} damage.

Additionally, choose any number of hostile creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. Each target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a target is {@condition weakness|GuildWars|weakened} for 1 round.

As the Spirit of ferocity and confidence and the natural embodiment of all bears, Bear is the most revered of all the Spirits of the Wild and is said to be an icon of strength, insight, and wisdom. According to ancient myths, she bestowed the norn with the totem ability to Become the Bear. The norn view Bear as both a Mother who protects her cubs and a Sister who helps people find their inner strength. She is said to give norn the power to face all odds, but some norn are aware that she can also strike with surprising speed. Because of the ursine appearance of the kodan, some norn believe that the kodan are blessed by Bear. Some followers of Bear claim that she has appeared in their dreams to give them guidance.

action.name: Ursan Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 4d8 + 7}) piercing damage, plus 16 ({@damage 5d6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Ursan Rage {@recharge 5}
entries: Choose one creature that you can see within 5-feet of you. Target each creature other than you in a 5-foot-radius centered on the target. Make a melee attack against each target. On a hit, a target takes {@damage 6d6 + 7} slashing damage and must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, a target is knocked {@condition prone}.

bonus.name: Ursan Force {@recharge 4}
entries: For 3 rounds, your speed is increased by 25 feet, and you cannot be knocked {@condition prone}.

bonus.name: Ursan Roar {@recharge}
entries: Choose any number of friendly creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. For 1 round, the next time a target hits with a weapon attack, they deal an additional {@damage 4d6} damage.

Additionally, choose any number of hostile creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. Each target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a target is {@condition weakness|GuildWars|weakened} for 4 rounds.

As the Spirit of ferocity and confidence and the natural embodiment of all bears, Bear is the most revered of all the Spirits of the Wild and is said to be an icon of strength, insight, and wisdom. According to ancient myths, she bestowed the norn with the totem ability to Become the Bear. The norn view Bear as both a Mother who protects her cubs and a Sister who helps people find their inner strength. She is said to give norn the power to face all odds, but some norn are aware that she can also strike with surprising speed. Because of the ursine appearance of the kodan, some norn believe that the kodan are blessed by Bear. Some followers of Bear claim that she has appeared in their dreams to give them guidance.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bone fiend makes a number of Spike attacks equal to half the level of the spell (rounded down) (minimum 1).

action.name: Spike
entries: {@atk} {@hit 3 + PB} to hit, range 80/120 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.
Bone Horrors are minions created by certain Necromancer skills (Animate Bone Horror, Malign Intervention, and Aura of the Lich) and the Minion Apocalypse Flux.
The Prize Moa Bird belonged to Pitney, before it disappeared deep into The Catacombs.

action.name: Impress
entries: Madam Featherbutt puts on a show for a spectral penal of judges. She does a performance check, and depending on the result, gains one of the following benefits:
1-10: Not impressed! — Madam Featherbutt has disadvantage on all saving throws until the end of her turn.
11-20: Impressive! — Madam Featherbutt has advantage on all saving throws until the end of her turn.
21+: Truly Magnanimous! — Madam Featherbutt has done such a good job impressing the judges that she gains plot armor and is immune to all damage and conditions until the DM decides otherwise.

reaction.name: "Not my prized Moa bird!"
entries: Madam Featherbutt can choose not to take damage from any source.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: Madam Featherbutt doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when she flies out of an enemy's reach.

legendary.name: Flutter
entries: Madam Featherbutt moves up to her speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

trait.name: Cunning Action
entries: On each of his turns, Rornark Stonesledge can use a bonus action to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

trait.name: Sneak Attack
entries: Once per turn, Rornark Stonesledge can deal an extra 7 ({@dice 2d6}) damage when he hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of Rornark Stonesledge that isn't {@condition incapacitated} and Rornark Stonesledge doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Rornark Stonesledge makes two shortsword attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage, or 19 ({@damage 4d6 + 5}) piercing damage while enlarged.

action.name: Hand Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage.

Rornak Stonesledge is a Deldrimor spy who is frequently captured by enemy forces. He can be encountered during three missions in the Shiverpeaks, and in each case when freed by the player he initiates the mission's bonus objective.

He can first be encountered in Borlis Pass after having been caught by the Stone Summit forces in Maladar's Fort, where he learned of a plan to unleash an Ice Drake on Grooble's Gulch. When he is freed, he beseeches the player character to find and kill the Ice Drake. He is soon captured again on the path to the Frost Gate while trying to steal the Stone Summit's Secret Siege Weapon Plans. He is left in a dryder cave, and when rescued he enlists the player character's help to steal the plans, and repairs a Stone Summit ballista to blast open the gate protecting them.

He can be found a third time, much later, in the Ice Caves of Sorrow, this time a prisoner of the Mursaat after he was caught scouting for an alternative way into the White Mantle prison camp. When he is freed once more, he asks that Hamdor Grandaxe's rescue party be told where he is.

reaction.name: Invoke the Great Dwarf
entries: Once per day, if Rornark Stonesledge fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

As the Spirit of knowledge and foresight and the natural embodiment of ravens, Raven is said to be a trickster who is fond of riddles and wordplay and likes to test the wits of his followers and anyone else who wishes to uncover his secrets. He calls his followers fledglings, inspires artists, and also favors acts of kindness towards ravens who are viewed as his flock. In some cases Raven is believed to personally come to take the life of a norn who was about to die and guide the soul to the Mists.

The norn believe that Raven sees and knows all, and requires nothing but the petitioner's promise to always seek wisdom to grant them his blessing of swiftness. He only views someone unworthy in his eyes if the person does not learn from their mistakes, and he rewards the clever, the sincere, and those who seek out new experiences such as traveling the world.Although Raven represents the facets of mind that grant beings the vision to see and the wisdom to understand, his teachings also contain a darker side.

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The corvid transformation has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, hearing or smell.

action.name: Raven Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d4 + 5}) slashing damage. On hit, the target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or become {@condition crippled|GuildWars} and start {@condition bleeding|GuildWars}, taking {@damage 1d4} damage, for 1 minute.
At the end of each of its turns, the target can make a Constitution saving throw for each condition affecting it. On a success, that condition ends.

action.name: Raven Swoop {@recharge 5}
entries: Choose one creature that you can see within 5-feet of you. Target each creature other than you in a 5-foot-radius centered on the target. Make a melee attack against each target. On a hit, a target takes {@damage 4d4 + 5} slashing damage.

bonus.name: Raven Flight {@recharge 4}
entries: For 1 round, you gain a flying speed of 30 feet, and you cannot be knocked {@condition prone}.

bonus.name: Raven Shriek {@recharge}
entries: Choose any number of friendly creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. End the {@condition blinded} condition on each target.

Additionally, choose any number of hostile creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. Each target must make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, a target is {@condition blinded} for 1 round.

As the natural embodiment of all owls, Owl was revered as one of the Spirits of the Wild among the norn. Although she was a gentle Spirit who embodied home and hearth, she was also a silent and clever predator with ambush-like swiftness and precision. Helping the sick and wounded pleased her. Owl put her family's needs and safety above all else, often teaching others that the purpose of the hunt was not just to kill but also to provide and protect. Tales about Owl depict her offering her wisdom to both norn and her fellow Spirits of the Wild.

action.name: Owl Flyby {@recharge 5}
entries: Choose one creature that you can see within 5-feet of you. Target each creature other than you in a 5-foot-radius centered on the target. Make a melee attack against each target. On a hit, a target takes {@damage 4d10 + 5} slashing damage and can't use reactions.

bonus.name: Owl Flight {@recharge 4}
entries: For 2 rounds, you gain a flying speed of 60 feet, and you cannot be {@condition restrained} or {@condition grappled}.

bonus.name: Owl Cry {@recharge}
entries: Choose any number of friendly creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. Each target doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when they exit an enemy's reach for 3 rounds.

Additionally, choose any number of hostile creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. Each target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a target is {@condition frightened} for 3 rounds.

As the natural embodiment of all owls, Owl was revered as one of the Spirits of the Wild among the norn. Although she was a gentle Spirit who embodied home and hearth, she was also a silent and clever predator with ambush-like swiftness and precision. Helping the sick and wounded pleased her. Owl put her family's needs and safety above all else, often teaching others that the purpose of the hunt was not just to kill but also to provide and protect. Tales about Owl depict her offering her wisdom to both norn and her fellow Spirits of the Wild.

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The strigid transformation has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, hearing or smell.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The strigid transformation doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it exits an enemy's reach.

entries: For 1 minute, you gain a flying speed of 90 feet, and you cannot be {@condition restrained} or {@condition grappled}.

entries: Choose any number of friendly creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. Each target doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when they exit an enemy's reach for 1 minute.

Additionally, choose any number of hostile creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. Each target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a target is {@condition frightened} for 1 minute.

As the Spirit of teamwork, friendship, family, and the natural embodiment of all wolves, Wolf is said to be dedicated to brotherhood as he imparts the virtues of loyalty, ferocity, and strength in numbers. He is revered as a masculine spirit, and the norn call him their brother, son, father, and uncle when they ask for his blessing. According to old tales, Owl taught Wolf how his hunting would be for naught if his family dined alone, making Wolf heed Owl's wisdom as he returned to his cubs. Although in some cases Raven was believed to personally come to take the life of a norn who was about to die and guide the soul to the Mists, Wolf was also known to do the same to people who walked in his footsteps.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The volfen transformation has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The volfen transformation has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the volfen transformation's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Volfen Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) damage. On hit, the target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or gain a {@condition deep wound|GuildWars} for 2 rounds.
At the end of each of its turns, a target can make a Constitution saving throw. On a success, the condition ends.

bonus.name: Volfen Agility {@recharge 4}
entries: For 1 round, increase the range in which your recharge abilities recharge by 1.

bonus.name: Volfen Pounce {@recharge 5}
entries: For 1 round, your speed is increased by 20% and the next time you hit with an attack, it deals an additional {@damage 1d12} damage in a 5-foot radius around the attack target, ignoring you.

bonus.name: Volfen Bloodlust {@recharge}
entries: Choose any number of friendly creatures that can hear you and are within 150-feet of you. For 1 round, each target can attack one additional time when they take the attack action on their turn.

legendaryGroup.name: Bonfaaz Burntfur
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (winning initiative ties), Bonfaaz Burntfur can take a lair action to cause one of the following magical effects; Bonfaaz Burntfur can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

- Choose three points that he can see, designating them for destruction. An ominous sound can be heard when standing within 10-feet of a designated point. At initiative 0, a 3rd level {@spell Meteor|GuildWars} will impact at the chosen points.
- Bonfaaz Burntfur rallies the charr troops, increasing their morale and improving their abilities. All allied charr gain 10 temporary hit points.
regionalEffects: If the Stormcaller horn has been blown, all charr become vulnerable to all damage, and deal only half damage.

entries.name: Age
entries: Norn can have long lives, living up to 120 and maintaining their good health and vitality for a long time, though very few die of old age.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid. You are also considered a shapeshifter for any prerequisite or effect that requires you to be a shapeshifter.

entries.name: Size
entries: Norn are around 9 feet tall and have broad builds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Menacing
entries: You gain proficiency in the Intimidation skill.

entries.name: Cold Climate Adaptation
entries: You have resistance to cold damage and can't be slowed down or hindered by snowy or icy terrain.

entries.name: Become your Totem
entries: Once per Long Rest you can choose to transform into your Totem animal as an action. When transforming choose an Animal with a CR of 1 ⁄ 4 your Level or lower from the list of available totem animals for your Sub-Race.
Wild Shape rules apply.

entries.name: Raven's Cunning
entries: When rolling initiative you can add your Intelligence ability modifier in addition to your Dexterity ability modifier to it.

entries.name: Age
entries: Humans reach adulthood in their late teens and live less than a century.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid.

entries.name: Size
entries: Humans are around 5 1/2 feet tall and have a wide variety of builds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Favoured by the Gods
entries: When choosing this race choose a patron god. The patron god gives you a small amount of power in the form a cantrip, a spell and a resistance to a specific damage type. Your spellcasting ability for those spells is dependent on the god. You can cast the spell once per short rest.

Damage Resistance: Radiant

entries: You can choose a second patron god for the Favored by the Gods feature. You can also cast each spell twice per short rest.

entries.name: Age
entries: Humans reach adulthood in their late teens and live less than a century.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid.

entries.name: Size
entries: Humans are around 5 1/2 feet tall and have a wide variety of builds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Favoured by the Gods
entries: When choosing this race choose a patron god. The patron god gives you a small amount of power in the form a cantrip, a spell and a resistance to a specific damage type. Your spellcasting ability for those spells is dependent on the god. You can cast the spell once per short rest.

entries.name: Dwayna
entries: Spellcasting ability: Wisdom
Cantrip: {@spell Guidance|phb}
Spell: {@spell Orison of Healing|GuildWars}
Damage Resistance: Radiant

entries.name: Grenth
entries: Spellcasting ability: Intelligence
Cantrip: {@spell Toll the Dead|xge}
Spell: {@spell Deathly Swarm|GuildWars}
Damage Resistance: Necrotic

entries.name: Balthazar
entries: Spellcasting ability: Strength
Cantrip: {@spell Green-Flame Blade|tce}
Spell: {@spell Frenzy|GuildWars}
Damage Resistance: Fire

entries.name: Melandru
entries: Spellcasting ability: Dexterity
Cantrip: {@spell Thorn Whip|phb}
Spell: {@spell Charm Animal|GuildWars}
Damage Resistance: Poison and Acid

entries.name: Lyssa
entries: Spellcasting ability: Charisma
Cantrip: {@spell Minor Illusion|phb}
Spell: {@spell Empathy|GuildWars}
Damage Resistance: Psychic

entries.name: Trained Actor
entries: You can add a d4 to any Charisma (Performance) or Charisma (Deception) ability check.

You can also try to pretend to be dead if you make death saving throws. To do so you must win a contested Charisma (Performance) or Charisma (Deception) ability check against an enemy's Wisdom (Insight) ability check that tries to target you with an attack. If you succeed, that enemy thinks you are dead and does not target you with an attack. If they succeed they see though your deception and can attack normally.

entries.name: Age
entries: Charr reach adulthood in their late teens and live less than a century.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid.

entries.name: Size
entries: Charr are around 7 feet tall and have a wide build. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Cat's Talent
entries: You have proficiency in the Perception and Stealth skills.

entries.name: Military Training
entries: You have proficiency with all simple and non-two-handed martial weapons.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You discern colors in that darkness only as shades of grey.

entries.name: Cat's Claws
entries: You can use your claws to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with them, the strike deals 1d6 + your Strength/Dexterity modifier slashing damage, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

entries.name: Savage Attacks
entries: When you score a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you can roll one of the weapon's damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.

entries.name: Expert Assassin
entries: When attacking from hiding or attacking a surprised creature your weapon attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20. If another feature or trait already gives you an increased critical hit range, increase that range by one instead.

entries.name: Superior Equipment Knowledge
entries: You have proficiency with all weapons and armors. If you already have proficiency with all weapons and armors, you instead gain proficiency with two additional languages or tools and two skills of your choice.

entries.name: Infernal Magic
entries: You know the fire bolt cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the fire bolt storm spell as a 2nd-level spell with this trait; you regain the ability to cast it when you finish a long rest. Once you reach 5th level, you can also cast the lava font spell as a 3rd-level spell with this trait; you regain the ability to cast it when you finish a long rest. Once you reach 7th level, you can also cast the meteor spell as 4th-level spell with this trait; you regain the ability to cast it when you finish a long rest. Intelligence, Wisdom or Charisma can be the spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Age
entries: Dwarves mature at the same rate as humans, but they're considered young until they reach the age of 50. On average, they live about 350 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Dwarves stand between 4 and 5 feet tall and average about 150 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your speed is not reduced by wearing heavy armor.

entries.name: Superior Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 120 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Dwarven Combat Training
entries: You have proficiency with all simple weapons and the {@item battleaxe|phb}, {@item handaxe|phb}, {@item light hammer|phb}, and {@item warhammer|phb}.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with the artisan's tools of your choice: {@item Smith's tools|phb}, {@item brewer's supplies|phb}, or {@item mason's tools|phb}.

entries.name: Dwarven Combat Training
entries: You have proficiency with all simple weapons and the {@item battleaxe|phb}, {@item handaxe|phb}, {@item light hammer|phb}, and {@item warhammer|phb}.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with the artisan's tools of your choice: {@item Smith's tools|phb}, {@item brewer's supplies|phb}, or {@item mason's tools|phb}.

entries.name: Invoke the Great Dwarf
entries: As a reaction when you fail a saving throw you can send out a prayer to the great Dwarf. When you do so you succeed on that saving throw instead. Once you use this feature you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Dwarven Toughness
entries: Your hit point maximum increases by 1, and it increases by 1 every time you gain a level.

entries.name: Age
entries: Dwarves mature at the same rate as humans, but they're considered young until they reach the age of 50. On average, they live about 350 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Dwarves stand between 4 and 5 feet tall and average about 150 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your speed is not reduced by wearing heavy armor.

entries.name: Superior Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 120 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Dwarven Combat Training
entries: You have proficiency with all simple weapons and the {@item battleaxe|phb}, {@item handaxe|phb}, {@item light hammer|phb}, and {@item warhammer|phb}.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with the artisan's tools of your choice: {@item Smith's tools|phb}, {@item brewer's supplies|phb}, or {@item mason's tools|phb}.

entries.name: Invoke the Great Destroyer
entries: When you take damage, you can send out a prayer to the great Destroyer. When you do so, you can cast {@spell Hellish Rebuke|PHB} at a level equal to your Proficiency Bonus. Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Dwarven Armor Training
entries: You have proficiency with all armors. If you already have proficiency with all armors, you gain proficiency with two skills of your choice.

raceFluff.name: Norn
entries: The Norn are a race of nine-foot-tall warriors who live in the northernmost Shiverpeaks. They revel in the harsh climes, leading dangerous lives among savage beasts. These mighty hunters are not organised into a single nation. Instead, those who display exceptional strength and prowess in battle establish homesteads, though they are certainly not considered 'rulers'. They often spend years at a time tracking a particularly strong or clever quarry; they never give up on a battle, a pursuit, or a friend.

The Norn revere the spirits of nature—from the wolf to the snow lynx -- but the most powerful of these is the Bear Spirit, who, according to myth, blessed the Norn with the ability to change shape and 'become the bear'.

A race of shape-shifting half-giants from the north, the Norn value personal strength, victory, and purifying the soul through battle. They revere the spirits of animals and call on them like shamans.

The Norn are a highly independent race with a fighter-centric society, holding strength and prowess in combat above everything else. To a Norn, the greatest shame is not dying in battle, but rather not having the tale of their life, especially death, told. Due to their independence, the Norn are hardly seen in large parties with the exception of great hunts, festivities, and in the larger homesteads like Gunnar's Hold.

For the Norn, in order to wed, the couple must be of equal reputation, and marriage symbolises the combining of their tales. During the wedding, someone must speak on the behalf of the two to show their worth for the other.

Norn culture is highly individualistic with a focus on personal success and glory—particularly when gained from the hunt or in a battle. The norn do not fear death as they believe the bold and strong can achieve immortality, but they do fear they will be weak and end up forgotten. As a result each norn seeks to prove themselves, to build their legend through feats of individual valour and great victories. Every norn hopes their legend will be told by the skaald and celebrated at a moot with story and song. Norn usually have a great sense of personal honour, for a norn without respect from others is already forgotten. For many norn, the focus on prestige means they're willing to accept any challenge which will prove their worth. They will never give up on their battle, quarry or friends, even if it means years spent tackling a strong enemy or difficult task. Yet for other norn the pursuit of prestige translates to bragging, bullying, unwise snap decisions and an unwillingness to listen to reason.

Norn are a hearty, proud people—quick to anger, but also to forgive. They are, by their nature, a race of optimists, keeping a positive outlook even though they have been driven from their homelands. A setback is seen as just another challenge to overcome. They respect those who can best them in a fight so brawling among norn is common. Drinking alcohol, often to excess, is also a large part of norn culture. Being drunk and fighting is not an uncommon combination, for example, norn alemoots feature competitions of 'skill' which require the competitors to be very drunk to compete.

A norn might proudly trace their worthy ancestors through many generations and may pass a common name through a family (such as Olaf Olafson, seventh son of Olaf) but a great ancestry and family connections do not grant automatic respect to a norn. Everyone is judged not by their lineage or associated group but by what deeds they have done. There is no such thing as infamy to the norn; they are often tolerant of an individual to whom other races might treat with hostility by association.

raceFluff.name: Norn (Spirit of Bear)
entries: As the Spirit of ferocity and confidence and the natural embodiment of all bears, Bear is the most revered of all the Spirits of the Wild and is said to be an icon of strength, insight, and wisdom. According to ancient myths, she bestowed the norn with the totem ability to Become the Bear. The norn view Bear as both a Mother who protects her cubs and a Sister who helps people find their inner strength. She is said to give norn the power to face all odds.

raceFluff.name: Norn (Spirit of Wolf)
entries: As the Spirit of teamwork, friendship, family, and the natural embodiment of all wolves, Wolf is said to be dedicated to brotherhood as he imparts the virtues of loyalty, ferocity, and strength in numbers. He is revered as a masculine spirit, and the norn call him their brother, son, father, and uncle when they ask for his blessing. According to old tales, Owl taught Wolf how his hunting would be for naught if his family dined alone, making Wolf heed Owl's wisdom as he returned to his cubs. Although in some cases Raven was believed to personally come to take the life of a norn who was about to die and guide the soul to the Mists, Wolf was also known to do the same to people who walked in his footsteps.

raceFluff.name: Norn (Spirit of Owl)
entries: As the natural embodiment of all owls, Owl was revered as one of the Spirits of the Wild among the norn. Although she was a gentle Spirit who embodied home and hearth, she was also a silent and clever predator with ambush-like swiftness and precision. Helping the sick and wounded pleased her. Owl put her family's needs and safety above all else, often teaching others that the purpose of the hunt was not just to kill but also to provide and protect. Tales about Owl depict her offering her wisdom to both norn and her fellow Spirits of the Wild.

raceFluff.name: Norn (Spirit of Raven)
entries: As the Spirit of knowledge and foresight and the natural embodiment of ravens, Raven is said to be a trickster who is fond of riddles and wordplay and likes to test the wits of his followers and anyone else who wishes to uncover his secrets. He calls his followers fledglings, inspires artists, and also favours acts of kindness towards ravens who are viewed as his flock. In some cases Raven is believed to personally come to take the life of a norn who was about to die and guide the soul to the Mists.

The norn believe that Raven sees and knows all, and requires nothing but the petitioner's promise to always seek wisdom to grant them his blessing of swiftness. He only views someone unworthy in his eyes if the person does not learn from their mistakes, and he rewards the clever, the sincere, and those who seek out new experiences such as travelling the world. Although Raven represents the facets of mind that grant beings the vision to see and the wisdom to understand, his teachings also contain a darker side which some of his wayward shamans would cruelly embrace in their quest for knowledge and power at the expense of others.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Human
entries: Humans are one of the most widespread and influential species in the world of Tyria. They are spread throughout the world of Tyria, including Cantha, Elona, and the eponymous continent Tyria, though it is implied they live further south than Cantha, which is where they may have originated.
Wherever they originated, humans are not native to the world as they were brought there by the Six Gods. The gods themselves only predate humans by a short period of time.
Humans arrived on the Tyrian continent in 205 BE. Since their arrival, three major human polities have arisen, Ascalon, Kryta, and Orr. Orr was the first region colonised.

Before the Exodus of the Gods, the gods lived in Arah (nicknamed the City of the Gods) and aided humans in numerous tasks such as pushing the Charr north so that the settlements that would become known as Ascalon could be established. With their aid, King Doric became the first ruler of all human realms. It was he who prayed to Dwayna to stop a war in 115 BE; it was he who pleaded to the gods a year before the exodus to stop the many conflicts caused by the gift of magic being given too freely; and it is his blood that seals the bloodstones.

After the creation of the bloodstones, the colonies of Ascalon and Kryta gradually split off into their own kingdoms - turning the unified human kingdom into three. During this time, open conflicts raged between the various human guilds and are now referred to as the Guild Wars. The Guild Wars were so widespread that they drew the Tyrian human kingdoms into war with each other in order to stop the battling in their own streets. It took the foreign threat of Charr to finally bring an end to the internecine conflict. The event now known as the Charr invasion ravaged the three human kingdoms, forcing them to put aside their squabbling or face destruction.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Human (Ascalonian)
entries: Ascalon is a land filled with wheat fields, blossoming flowers, and natural irrigation throughout the fertile landscape. Ascalon is located between the Shiverpeak Mountains and the Blazeridge Mountains.

During the last Guild War, the people of Rin looked to Adelbern to lead them; he was crowned king due to his feats and popularity. Duke Barradin was the next heir to the throne before Adelbern was crowned and, as such, some of his supporters were not happy when a soldier was named instead. Some royalists, including nobles and members of the court, became bandits and took to the countryside.
Even though Ascalon is a beautiful place, it is riddled with threats from Skale, Grawl, bandits, and the Charr.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Human (Krytan)
entries: Kryta was the third and last human kingdom to be established in Tyria. Originally a colony of Elona, it was established in 300 AE, it gained its independence in 358 AE. The kingdom's royal family are descendants of King Doric, however it is not known how far Doric's lineage goes into the Krytan royalty. There have been few notable members of this royalty, outside the last king, King Jadon, the only known monarch is Mad King Thorn. Those of the royal bloodline are buried in the Mausoleum, which is guarded by the undead dragon Rotscale.

Kryta is home to many important landmarks, such as the Wizard's Tower and the Temple of the Ages. It is also the origin of the now-mysterious Druids, former Krytans who left into the Maguuma Jungle to the west long ago.
Sometime in the distant past, several large watchtowers were built along the northern coast to defend Kryta against a threat to the north.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Human (Orrian)
entries: Situated on a peninsula south of Ascalon and west of the Crystal Desert, Orr was a vibrant, proud, and prosperous nation. Its citizens were the favoured of the gods, living in the shadows of Arah, the deserted city once inhabited by the likes of Melandru, Dwayna, and Balthazar. Deeply spiritual, the Orrians looked after the buildings and structures left behind when the gods left Tyria, caring for them in the hopes that one day, the divine beings who created magic and bestowed it upon the world would return.

The Orrians were a peaceful people, hoping only to do their duty toward their gods and content to be rewarded in either this life or the next. When the guilds began feuding, Orr as a nation tried to stay out of the conflict. This was not the sort of struggle that entire kingdoms got involved in. But when the strife overflowed into armed conflict, and guilds from the other human nations began fighting in the streets of Arah, Orr rose to defend itself and the city of the gods.

Soon after Orr mobilised its armies, Kryta and Ascalon did as well, and what had started as a dispute between localised groups became an all-out war. The Guild Wars raged for nearly fifty years. During that time, none of the three human empires was able to assert dominance over either of the other two. While Ascalon, Orr, and Kryta were busy fighting with each other, they became blind to the threat from the north—the Charr.

The Kingdom of Orr was the first human kingdom established on the continent of Tyria, created by both god and man. From 100 BE, the kingdom was ruled alongside Ascalon by King Doric until his death in 1BE. Orr gained its independence in the year 2 AE. At the time of the Second Great Corsair War and King Zoran's reign, Orrian territory is known to have extended into the Tarnished Coast, and included the caverns now known as the Shards of Orr. Orr was once the most vibrant, proud, and prosperous human nation in the known world. Its citizens believed themselves to be the favoured of the Six Human Gods, living in the shadows of Arah which was once inhabited by the gods themselves. Orr was known as the nexus of arcane activity and research.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Human (Vabbian)
entries: The northern province of Vabbi is known for its great wealth and refined culture. Merchant princes pride themselves on their large estates, prosperous businesses, and patronage of the arts. Its provincial government, the Grand Forum of Vabb, is a plutocracy: only the wealthiest princes in the land have the power to make laws. Their legislature is openly democratic, but secretly, a merchant with influence has more power than a counsellor with one vote.

Vabbian princes rule the land. Most plutocrats sponsor great festivals and celebrations to display their importance and influence. Celebrations in Vabbian estates are wonders to behold: Dancers flourish in their elegant fashions, gourmands sample cuisine, revellers consume epic quantities of alcohol, and cultured citizens enjoy great works of drama and poetry. Heroes are welcomed at these festivals, where their heroism is celebrated in songs and stories.

The Vabbi are effusive in displays of self-importance, but also keenly aware of how much they depend on other Elonians. The guards of Vabbian estates watch the mountain range to the north, while citizens on the province's southern border depend on neighbouring Kournans to keep them safe. Outside the walls of the grand estates, danger is everywhere. Raiders know secret passes through the mountains and mines, and monstrous creatures roam the landscape. Fortunately, every generation of Vabbi includes idealists who dream of adventurous journeys across Elona. New tales of adventure appear on the shelves of Vabbi's libraries each year, as actors portray new heroes on the stages of Vabbian theatres.

raceFluff.name: Charr
entries: The Charr are aggressive, industrious, and wholly dedicated to becoming the preeminent species of Tyria. A savage race of sentient beasts, the Charr will use any means available to destroy their enemies: an ambush is as honourable as a fair fight, as victory is what matters. Though Charr have no concept of mercy, they can be protective of those within their warband.

The Charr are a savage fighting race that once dominated the eastern side of the Shiverpeak Mountains. They fought anything they could - including themselves. Eventually the many warbands of the Charr united under a single leader: the Khan-Ur.

In the days before the Gods of Tyria brought the Humans to Tyria, the Charr battled with the Forgotten in the Blazeridge Mountains. Long after the Forgotten stopped threatening the Charr, the Humans appeared and, with the help of their Gods, pushed the Charr from their southern borders, conquering the land that became known as Ascalon in 100 BE. Along with being pushed back, the Khan-Ur was assassinated, preventing any hope the Charr had to retake their lands. The death of the Khan-Ur caused a schism among his four children, who became known as imperators, and brought the establishment of the High Legions - the Ash Legion, the Blood Legion, the Flame Legion, and the Iron Legion.

In order to combat the Humans, they sought gods to call their own, and at the volcano called Hrangmer, the Burnt Warband discovered gods for the Charr. Having found gods, the Shaman caste, the first Charr to unite under the new fiery gods, united the rest of the Charr warbands under their faith. Though one Charr, Bathea Havocbringer, rejected these new gods. She was quickly executed as a living sacrifice to the gods and the Shaman caste banned all female Charr from warbands and armies, sent to do utility work.

raceFluff.name: Charr (Blood Legion)
entries: The Blood Legion is one of the four High Legions in charr society. They are known for their prowess in traditional battlefield combat. The Blood Legion controls the largest known amount of territory of the charr, having both the Blood Legion Homelands as well as the lands on the eastern side of the Blazeridge Mountains.

raceFluff.name: Charr (Ash Legion)
entries: The Ash Legion is one of the four High Legions of the charr, famed for their spies, stalkers and assassins. They were formed by the Khan-Ur's spymaster, one of the Khan-Ur's children.

raceFluff.name: Charr (Iron Legion)
entries: The Iron Legion is one of the four High Legions of the Charr. The Iron Legion is known for its Siege Devourers, catapults, towers, and other mechanical works.

raceFluff.name: Charr (Flame Legion)
entries: The Flame Legion is one of the four High Legions of the Charr. The Flame Legion is renowned for its members' magical prowess and is most commonly associated with the Shaman caste.

To the Charr, flame is the physical representation of their gods. In order to keep the gods happy, they must first fulfil their obligation to the flame. To that end, the Charr have constructed a series of sacred buildings known as Flame Temples. On raised platforms, these bestial creatures have inscribed huge circular runes, which define and magically feed the sacred fires. Further defining the ring are pillars of pure obsidian or carved sandstone, sculpted to depict the faces of the mysterious creatures the Charr worship. Between these pillars, in the very centre of each of these temples, are the ever-burning Sacred Flames. The Charr believe that as long as the flames are burning, the gods are pleased. If the flames go out, then the Charr have failed in their duties and will be punished by the gods.

Each temple has its own fire, which is tended at all times by four Charr Flame Keepers. The Flame Keepers have only one job—to keep the Sacred Flame burning. This is the most prestigious position a Charr can occupy; only the strongest, most capable Charr can take this honour, and all other Charr bow to the Flame Keepers.

In addition to the temples, whenever a large Charr warband travels anywhere, they take with them a bronze brazier, lit at a Flame Temple by the Sacred Flame. These braziers are placed upon palanquins, which are then carried from location to location by four Charr Flame Carriers. Each night when they make camp, the Flame Carriers erect a flammable effigy in the shape of one of their gods, then ignite it and let it burn till daylight.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Dwarf
entries: One of the oldest races on Tyria, the Dwarves are humanoids that are stocky, short, and are almost always bearded. The dwarves live in the Shiverpeak Mountains - specifically the Northern Shiverpeaks and the Southern Shiverpeaks.

In recent years, the dwarves have been plunged into a civil war between the older Deldrimor dwarves and the recent Stone Summit faction. This war has caused unrest throughout the Shiverpeaks and held up most travel between Ascalon and the other human nations.

The exact origins of the dwarven race is unknown, but their legends claim that the Dwarves were forged by their god, the Great Dwarf, on Anvil Rock in the Northern Shiverpeaks. Over time the dwarves laid claim to the Shiverpeak Mountains, forming the Deldrimor nation. Though they traded with the human nations and were on generally good terms, the dwarves largely kept to themselves.

Sometime years prior to 1072 AE, Dagnar Stonepate, cousin to the ruling king, Jalis Ironhammer, created a splinter faction that opposed the Deldrimor. The Stone Summit was a group of xenophobic radicals who believed that it was the Dwarves' right to rule over all other races. Inevitably the friction between the two groups erupted into a civil war.
The Dwarves are a mining and smithing centric society with a monarchy.

Most of the Dwarves follow and worship the Great Dwarf as their creator and god. Outside of their creation legend, it is said that the Great Dwarf taught the Dwarves the fineness of crafting before he departed to the Great Forge, where all Dwarves go when they die. There are also dwarves who worship, or at least revere, Dwayna, Grenth, or the Great Destroyer. The dwarves who worship or revere Dwayna and Grenth only seem to appear during Wintersday. Many within the Stone Summit worship the Great Destroyer.
There is also a group of Dwarves within Deldrimor known as the Brotherhood of the Dragon who serve the oracle dragon Glint.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Dwarf (Deldrimor)
entries: Deldrimor is a kingdom of Dwarves residing in the Shiverpeak Mountains that are ruled by a king. They are very friendly towards other races and passage through the harsh mountain range is welcome to anyone who is a friend of Deldrimor or an enemy to the Stone Summit. They hold a capital in Thunderhead Keep.

raceFluff.name: Tyrian Dwarf (Stone Summit)
entries: The Stone Summit is a xenophobic faction which has recently broken away from the Deldrimor dwarves while being led by Dagnar Stonepate. They have had some recent successes in seizing power and resources from the Deldrimor Dwarves, most notably in claiming the vast mine of Sorrow's Furnace, which became their main base
